Why the low score? Always online. A ridiculous function that EA has been pursuing for years on their games and regardless of all the negative feedback on it they still stubbornly try to push it on games. Then try to justify it by letting a bunch of player drive around in the same city to make it feel more lively, but all that ends up happening is you have a bunch of people who will ram into each other and generally spoil the experience. But, this, still isn't the main bad thing. The always online function absolutely CRIPPLES the game experience. If you lose connection for a second, you're out. Sometimes your wraps and paints that get automatically saved to the cloud (why?) won't load at all.  In the end we all know what always online means: It means that a few years down the line you're going to sit with a game in your Origin library that cannot be played because the servers have been closed. Review: Always online. Nothing quite like latency in a single player race. Customization options are slim. None of the first 4 cars I bought had parts available for every option, and many of the options have only a single part. You can't remove stock spoilers, what? Besides that, almost every aftermarket spoiler in the game is a hilarious bosozoku park bench. The only good spoiler I found was theAlways online. Nothing quite like latency in a single player race. Customization options are slim. None of the first 4 cars I bought had parts available for every option, and many of the options have only a single part. You can't remove stock spoilers, what? Besides that, almost every aftermarket spoiler in the game is a hilarious bosozoku park bench. The only good spoiler I found was the cool ducktail on the Volvo.  The vinyl editor is better than old NFS games, but still rotten. Still no tools to line up your decals. Just a pair of racing stripes is stupid hard to get, and you STILL have to make separate stripes for the top and both bumpers. The interface is hair-pullingly frustrating.  Wow, I can tune my car to handle like a real one with the Grip setting? Doesn't matter, because more than half of this game involves drifting and it's absurdly difficult to drift a Grip car. Besides, who would want to race a car that has to use the brakes against cars that can whip into any corner at any speed by dumping momentum into a drift?  Manual shifting is junk. Double-tap the shifter to drop 2 gears, and you will drop one. Every shift forces you to clutch, shift, and declutch through each individual gear, including if you crash and need to reverse. It will take you at least a good 5 seconds to change from 6 to R. Also, you need to choose manual trans for every single car you buy. For some reason transmission is a tuning option instead of a user preference. I can't believe how much time I spent looking for it in the options menu.  Rubberbanding. Ugghhh, your skills still don't matter in an AI race. The AI will accelerate with Gs that would puree a human being if they think you're not looking. There is no way to gain a sizeable lead. The AI will stick to you like a burdock to a wool hat no matter how delicately you thread the corners, but a crash in some races will leave you fighting for 3rd place while the first two cars inexplicably rocket miles ahead of the pack.  Career progression is dumb. Finish a mission, and you'll just have to drive around until you get a call from your buddies. Besides that, there is no story to the missions. Race here, drift this, hit this speed. All of that is in the context of some bizarre PUSH YOURSELF mantra kind of like the one in Rivals, and there is no visible progression until the end of the campaign. My "bae" also made fun of me over the ridiculous and plotless cutscenes. She was probably just jelly. Fist bump? Oh, and Manu's hair. What?  Yes, it's always night time and usually raining. Looks good, but it gets pretty stale. The city is nice and it looks pretty good, but there are few real landmarks and appreciable vistas. In Rivals you'd turn a corner to see an incredible mountain range over the railing or a desert stretching to the peaks in the distance, but Ventura Bay is just a bunch of roads. The roads are laid out in a frustrating way. Highway dividers are placed in homicidal and nonsensical places. There can't be more than 5 traffic cars in the whole city, but they are always waiting in the racing line just around a corner. The road fatalities in Ventura Bay must be extreme.  The multiplayer is half-baked. Just like Rivals, you'll spend 5 minutes chasing someone and hoping for a race only to find that they've been racing AI the whole time and can't engage you. This game is advertised as being a combination of single and multiplayer, but it's really just single with a little crappy multiplayer baked in, and the two are in constant conflict. I hated the Speed Tests and Challenges in MW'12, but at least I could just jump into a multiplayer game then.  The cars are fun to drive, and they look great. The sound from the Viper is freaking phenomenal, and most of the other cars are no exception. Learning to thread the line is very satisfying in a gripped-up car. If only there were more opportunities to do that.  All in all, it's a decent game. It took a few of the good parts from the old games, all of the flaws, and added a few new headaches like always online to boot. The first few hours were a lot of fun but, in true EA fashion, the crap comes out of the woodwork as you play. I found myself more disappointed than thrilled. There was never a moment that I got caught up in the game - there is always some detail waiting to break the immersion. Really glad I paid the $5 for the All Access trial, because this game is worth closer to $30 for me than 60, or even worse 70 for the package that spoils the game by putting every 3rd driver in the Most Wanted BMW. (also, do you remember when demos were free? I do)… Expand

Review: I didn't have high expectations about this game, but hell... we cannot speak about any expectations since Most Wanted (2005). Still, i was interested about this game and now that EA offered a 10 hour trial access to the game, i finally had the chance to try it. I pretty much got what i expected. OfI didn't have high expectations about this game, but hell... we cannot speak about any expectations since Most Wanted (2005). Still, i was interested about this game and now that EA offered a 10 hour trial access to the game, i finally had the chance to try it. I pretty much got what i expected. The visual part of the game is a ten out of ten. the Frostbite engine is pretty as always. Of course there are some effects i could live without, but my eyes easily get used to them. The handling is ok, nothing outstanding like TDU2 or the Forza Horizon series. It needs time to learn it properly, but it's really not a challenge. Maybe drifting is a bit hard, i tried to avoid it as mush as i could, because i was very suck at it. The car selection is ok, but i think supercars like the Ferrari or Lamborghini has nothing to do in this game. It's about street racing. The customization is really gives the player much freedom, i was satisfied with it (i mean the amount as i could see) The city is well builded, the always raining anomaly didn't annoyed me as so many others. Do you remember Underground 2? Just play an hour with it, you'll see how often raining in that game too. But there are some issues with this game which are still refuse me to give a god damn euro to this game. Fist thing first, the non-stop online connection requirement is nothing but a backward to this game. YOu ALWAYS need to be connected to the internet, and it just only make things worse if you have a kinda slow connection. It not going to screw up your races or anything, but you will experience performance problems and lagging even in a SINGLE PLAYER RACE! You also cannot bring up the world map or the menu properly, the game will still run in the background. How am i suppose to scrape my head in the middle of the race? Of course you can go solo which means you don't have to share your map with random people who park in the very same racing spot where you just want to teleport, or place a marker. But it still requires internet connection of course... the AI is as braindead as it can be. I don't know how it was when the game got released on consoles... i heard people complaining about the horrible catch-up system, maybe it was fixed or spoiled, because for me it was almost impossible to get beaten, even if i screwed up a corner or missed a checkpoint. In the very few times when they somehow managed to overtake me, they just randomly crashed into the wall, without reason. And it not happened just one or two times... no. At least in every second or third race. Very depressing. I still wouldn't buy it even if it had a 90% OFF sale, because the online... just call it DRM; ruins the fun for me. Let me decide whenever i want to cruise with other players or not, don't force your **** on me. But it has the potential. Maybe if they would listen a bit more to the player feedbacks and rethink the game design, it could be an ok Need for Speed game. Until then, it's nothing just a kinda medium strenght shot.… Expand

I prefer grip style racing but, unfortunately, at least half of the races in the game are drift point races... which aren't actually races at all, it's just point stacking. Drifting is a very frustrating experience in the game too because other players are always online with you and will randomly crash into you, ruining a good turn here or a good drift there. You really don't have a choice, if you don't want to play drift style, this game really isn't for you. I wanted to like it, I really did. I got toward the end of the game and the RNG from the computers are completely stacked against you. One computer got a 40,000 point drift at the beginning of the race and no could catch up after that, and it seems to happen more often than not.  Pros:  -4k looks pretty good. Most noticeably on with the weather elements in the game. -There really is a lot of visual customization you can do.  Cons: -Online style like GTA5 is a good idea in theory, but when the other players will ruin your races it loses its appeal quickly. -RNG is the most random numbers generated of any game I have ever seen. Sometimes it is just pure luck. -The lines on the mini-map displaying your track are sometimes off and can lead you to a wrong part of the race, making you turn around. -You have to drift. Some races you can play grip style but for many you have to learn how to drift. A few forced drift races are okay but when most of the game is comprised of drifting, it takes away the element of choice. -RNG is against you with crashes and glitches too. ---Sometimes the smallest touch on a wall will flip you over with a crash scene ---Cops have literally glitched into my track on multiple occasions. Randomly popping up in the middle of the track and either glitched in place or what seems like server lag as a car will instantly move from one spot to another. -There aren't really a lot of cars to choose from compared to other NFS games. And some cars you can't even do any type of tuning.  Conclusion: If you're a drifter, you'll probably enjoy this game but you'll still be frustrated with the RNG this game delivers. There's nothing worse than being in the lead at the end of the race and then another player zooms by and smashes you, ending your lead at the final stretch. Review: Need for Speed (2015) is a decently good game, touting impressive visuals, an iffy cast and a remarkable, seamless experience that allows you to transition from cutscene to game without skipping a beat.  -Graphics-  NFS15 is hands down the most visually impressive NFS game in existence. Using EA's Frostbite engine, Ghost has made a photorealistic game that truly makes you feel likeNeed for Speed (2015) is a decently good game, touting impressive visuals, an iffy cast and a remarkable, seamless experience that allows you to transition from cutscene to game without skipping a beat.  -Graphics- NFS15 is hands down the most visually impressive NFS game in existence. Using EA's Frostbite engine, Ghost has made a photorealistic game that truly makes you feel like you're street racing in the heart of a living city. WIth incredible lighting and mediocre weather (just rain), this game shines in the graphics department.  -Gameplay- NFS is all about driving, and NFS15 gets it right. In terms of car control, you can customize many aspects to suit your driving and visual styles, as customization options are aplenty. The inclusion of support for steering wheels is a plus, but take note that Sony's Dualshock 4 controllers do have issues with this game (Xbox controllers only). The best aspect of this game's gameplay is hands-down the incredible seamless experience it delivers. From checking the map to entering and exiting cutscenes, everything is done in a beautifully polished way that makes the entire game seem like a non-stop sequence. The only loading you'll ever see is during the start-up - after that, you can cruise, crash and drift everywhere smoothly (even in multiplayer, given you've got a good internet connection of course).  -Audio- NFS can't really be commended for audio, as it's just 3rd-party songs and your standard automobile noises. But, the tracklist is quite nice.  -Story- NFS games in the past have had stories, but most of us don't buy them for the tales they tell. With that said, NFS15 doesn't have a solid story on its hands - instead, there are a lot of small cutscenes here and there that provide a nice little break from nearly crashing into everyone as you attempt to catch that perfect drift. They lack a lot of story, and the game is primarily about trying to get noticed in the automotive scene, which itself isn't enough for a "story" to ride on.  -Issues- As everyone's most probably talked about, the game requires an active internet connection to play. This is a terrible design by Ghost, as people may want to play offline due to internet-related issues or performance issues. It also doesn't help that most of the NFS community is doing something else, leaving you with a (pretty much) defunct multiplayer. Additionally, I did find fault that Ghost only allowed people to race from dusk to dawn - this does help the environment looks snappier, but can get quite tedious not being able to play with a "real" day/night cycle. Other than this glaring problem, I couldn't find anything else wrong with the game.  -Verdict- NFS15 is a fun game and is worth a buy if you're looking to spend a good 20+ hours racing around a photorealistic environment with hosts of amazing cars and various customization options. True, the game does have many issues, but I feel that the online-only restriction is an option that shut out prospective buyers due to its "DRM" nature (and performance inhibitor) and should ward off buyers who value DRM-free games.… Expand

Customization is outstanding. Customization is the most realistic kind, only with aftermarket brands. Some cars have lots of customization, some have little, and a little have not at all. There are 53 cars in the game but the objective of the cars is perfecting not collecting. The cars also are built inside the game. Your customized car can be in the cutscene.  The career is split into 5 ways to play. Speed, Style, Build, Crew, Outlaw. The main elements in Need For Speed. With real life icons and actors who look up to these people.  Police chases are not as aggressive as what was in NFS Rivals but more fairer, less buggy and more playable. Roadblocks, spike strips, and the actual cruisers feel more realistic and fun. Some roadblock slow you down but you still pass them, while roadblocks made with cement blocks and rhino units are impossible to pass unless you find an extra road. The pursuit levels come into 5 levels. You can simply pay a fine and get the pursuit over with but that's not as fun. You need to pester them enough in order to get on with the pursuit. While starting in a pursuit, you are chased by 1 cop, but overtime you will be chased by a few more. This isn't the worst, but it's far from the best of the series.  PROs Graphics are excellent Cut-scenes are fun and pretty well acted Nice range of cars. First time I've seen a Volvo in a racing game! Good upgrade options for car mods, paint, etc. Realistic (ish) city layout  CONs Nice graphics are less relvant when it's dark all the time. And the city is boring TBH, nothing like the variety found in Most Wanted (either of them) Car handling is pretty awful - way too arcadey. No feel going round corners, poor force-feedback on the wheel. As bad as Undercover I would say - and that's pretty bad. Lack of control options - can't use the mouse in the map and can't map certain keys to the wheel buttons, so you're always reaching for the keyboard for PgUp, PgDn, etc.. And who uses Backspace to get to the menu! No proper manual gearbox - only flappy paddles :-( Races are too short. Not expecting 4-hour race a la The Crew, but 5-6 minutes would be nice. 2 minutes a shot is just too damn short. No mirrors or even a look-back function makes MP racing frustrating. The gameplay is rather vaugue and pointless. Sure you have free-roam, but you quite quickly start to wonder why you even care. There's just not that much to do.  Overall, a poor entry into the series and certainly not worth the asking price, not by a long way. It tries to be NFS Underground 3, but it's not. They should have just remade Undergound 2, pixel for pixel - that would have been better. However, it's not awful and will offer a degree of fun for an evening or two. Wait for it to hit the £10 mark (if it ever does) and snap it up.  But it's not awful… Expand
